page.title: 12HOLBEAM WOOD
page.content: Holbeam Wood is one of the stretches of deciduous woodland to run along the valley sides in Throwley. Originally most of this wood was beech, but this has been mainly replaced this century by a natural growth of birch, hazel (abundance) sycamore and oak. Much of this was coppiced about 30 years ago, but has now regrown to its full height. The woodland is in the North Downs Conservation Area. Evenso about 9 acres of Holbeam Wood was removed recently to provide more arable land. Most of the larger standard trees have preservation orders on them. The wood is a haven for wildlife, especially of woodland flowers. We found several fine specimens of spotted orchid. The ground is carpeted by bluebells in the spring. Pheasants are encouraged to breed in the wood.
